titleStmt.title: H ∞ Model Reduction of Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy Stochastic Systems

affiliation.orgName: are with the Space Control and Inertial Technology Research Center
Department of Computing and Mathematical Sciences

analytic.title: H ∞ Model Reduction of Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy Stochastic Systems

biblStruct.note: received August 8, 2010; revised October 3, 2011, December 29, 2011, and March 12, 2012; accepted April 8, 2012. Date of publication May 18, 2012; date of current version November 14, 2012.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is concerned with the problem of H ∞ model reduction for Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy stochastic systems. For a given mean-square stable T-S fuzzy stochastic system, our attention is focused on the construction of a reduced-order model, which not only approximates the original system well with an H ∞ performance but also translates it into a linear lower dimensional system. Then, the model reduction is converted into a convex optimization problem by using a linearization procedure, and a projection approach is also presented, which casts the model reduction into a sequential minimization problem subject to linear matrix inequality constraints by employing the cone complementary linearization algorithm. Finally, two numerical examples are provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

such as the H ∞ (or say, energy-to-energy) approach [11], [28], [32], the L 2 -L ∞ approach [15], [27], the H 2 approach [33], [34], [39], and the Hankel-norm approach [10], [19]. Very recently, the linear matrix inequality (LMI) [5] technique has been explored to solve the model reduction problem for different classes of systems in effect, involving time-delay systems [11], [27], switched hybrid systems [28], [35], and Markovian jump systems [38]. To the best of the authors' knowledge, little progress has been made for the model reduction of Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy systems, except for model approximation for discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems [30], since it is not easy to get the reduced-order T-S fuzzy systems for original T-S fuzzy systems due to the selected choice of how to confirm the member functions for the ideal reducedorder systems and how to choose the subsystems for the ideal reduced-order systems. However, limited results are available for continuous-time T-S fuzzy systems, which motivates this research work.

Since most physical systems and processes in real world are nonlinear, which introduce serious difficulties in system analysis and design, researchers have been devoting their efforts to seeking an effective means of approximating nonlinear systems. It is an effective method to analysis and synthesis nonlinear systems with the advent of the T-S fuzzy model [26]. It has been proved that T-S fuzzy models can approximate any smooth nonlinear system to any accuracy on a compact set, which is presented by a family of fuzzy IF-THEN rules that represent local linear input-output relations of the system. The general fuzzy model of the system is obtained through the blending of piecewise smooth membership functions. So far, a great number of results have been reported for T-S fuzzy systems. Recently, the analysis and control of T-S fuzzy systems have been considerably studied [1], [7], [8], [13], [18], [21]- [25], [31]. On the other hand, stochastic modeling has come to play an important role in many branches of engineering applications [12]. Therefore, the study of stochastic systems has been of great interest, and many results can be found in the literature. To mention a few, the problem of designing controllers is studied in [4], [36], and [37]. The problem of filtering is investigated in [17] and [20], and the problem of model reduction is considered in [19] and [32]. However, to the best of the authors' knowledge, few results on model approximation for T-S fuzzy stochastic systems are available, and it still remains challenging. Thus, research in this area should be of both theoretical importance and practical importance, which motivate us to carry out the present work.

Motivated by the fact that it is an effective way to describe a nonlinear system by employing the fuzzy set, in this paper, we investigate the H ∞ model reduction for a class of nonlinear Itô stochastic systems, which can be modeled as a T-S fuzzy linear Itô stochastic system (a weighted sum of some simple linear stochastic subsystems). Research in this area should be interesting yet challenging as it involves the combination of two classes of important systems, namely, stochastic systems and fuzzy systems. It should be pointed out that, so far, there have been only limited works that have taken the stochastic phenomena into account in the fuzzy systems [17], [29].

Furthermore, stochastic modeling has come to play an important role in many branches of engineering, economics, and finance. For example, in the actual power transmission engineering, with improving of model accuracy and practical problem complexity, more and more uncertain factors are considered in the model establishment. By establishing the corresponding stochastic modeling, the power transmission problems are analyzed, and the power transmission system is controlled. On the other hand, the dynamics of asset prices are reflected by uncertain movements of their values over time. Modeling the asset price is concerned with modeling the arrival of new information, such as efficient market hypothesis, which is one possible reason for the random behavior of the asset price. A Brownian motion process can be used to approximate an efficient market hypothesis, and stochastic modeling can be employed to research the asset price in the Brownian-motionbased process.

In this paper, the problem of H ∞ model reduction is studied for continuous-time T-S fuzzy stochastic systems. For a given mean-square stable T-S fuzzy stochastic system, our attention is focused on the construction of a reduced-order model, which approximates the original system well in an H ∞ sense. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The problem formulation and some preliminaries are presented in Section II. Section III gives our main results. Numerical examples are provided in Section IV, and we conclude this paper in Section V.

Notations: The notations used throughout this paper are fairly standard. "T" stands for matrix transposition, R n denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space, the notation P > 0 means that P is real symmetric and positive definite, I and 0 represent the identity matrix and a zero matrix, respectively, diag(. . .) stands for a block diagonal matrix, E{•} denotes the expectation operator, • denotes the Euclidean norm of a vector and its induced norm of a matrix, and the signals that are square integrable over [0, ∞) are denoted by L 2 [0, ∞) with the norm • 2 . Moreover, let (Ω, F, {F t } t≥0 , P) be a complete probability space with a filtration {F t } t≥0 satisfying the usual conditions (i.e., the filtration contains all P-null sets and is continuous). For a matrix U ∈ R m×n with rank k, we denote U ⊥ as the orthogonal complement, which is defined as a (possibly nonunique) (mk) × m matrix with rank (mk), such that U ⊥ U = 0; we denote U + as the Moore-Penrose inverse of U , and U L and U R are any full rank factors of U , i.e., U L U R = U . In symmetric block matrices, we use a star ( ) to represent a term that is induced by symmetry. Matrices, if their dimensions are not explicitly stated, are assumed to be compatible for algebraic operations.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION AND PRELIMINARIES
div.p: In this paper, we consider a class of nonlinear stochastic systems which can be described by the following T-S fuzzy stochastic model.

div.head: Plant Form: Rule
div.formula: i: IF θ 1 (t) is μ i1 and θ 2 (t) is μ i2 and • • • and θ p (t) is μ ip THEN dx(t) = [A i x(t) + B i u(t)] dt + E i x(t)d y(t) = C i x(t) + D i u(t), i= 1, 2, . . . , r(1)
div.p: where μ i1 , . It is assumed that the premise variables do not depend on the input variables u(t). Given a pair of (x(t), u(t)), the final output of the fuzzy stochastic systems (Σ) is inferred as follows:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ dx(t) = r i=1 h i (θ(t)) {[A i x(t) + B i u(t)] dt + E i x(t)d } y(t) = r i=1 h i (θ(t)) {C i x(t) + D i u(t)} (2) where h i (θ(t)) = ν i (θ(t)) r i=1 ν i (θ(t)) , ν i (θ(t)) = p j=1 μ ij (θ j (t))
div.p: where μ ij (θ j (t)) is the grade of the membership of θ j (t) in μ ij . Supposing that ν i (θ(t)) ≥ 0, with i = 1, 2, . . . , r, r i=1 ν i (θ(t)) > 0 for all t. Therefore, h i (θ(t)) ≥ 0 for i = 1, 2, . . . , r, and r i=1 h i (θ(t)) = 1 for all t. Remark 1: The membership functions h i (θ(t)) are associated with terms that appear in the antecedents or consequents of fuzzy rules in engineering applications of T-S fuzzy logic. It should be pointed out that the membership functions constructed in T-S fuzzy logic systems are employed to approximate both the nonlinear function and its derivative exactly in engineering applications, such as the tunnel diode in Example 2. The most commonly used shapes for membership functions are triangular, trapezoidal, piecewise linear, and Gaussian. Choosing of membership functions mainly depends upon the user's experiences, but membership functions should meet the conditions of h i (θ(t)) ≥ 0 and r i=1 h i (θ(t)) = 1 for i = 1, 2, . . . , r and all time.
Here, we will approximate the system (Σ) in ( 2) by a reduced-order system ( Σ) described by
div.formula: dx(t) = Âx(t) + Bu(t) dt + Ê x(t)d ŷ(t) = Ĉ x(t) + Du(t) (3)
div.p: where x(t) ∈ R k is the state vector of the reduced-order system ( Σ) with k < n and Â, B, Ĉ, D, and Ê are appropriately dimensioned matrices to be determined later.
Augmenting the model of (Σ) to include the states of ( Σ), we obtain the error system ( Σc ) as
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ dξ(t)= r i=1 h i (θ(t)) Ãi ξ(t)+ Bi u(t) dt+ Ẽi ξ(t)d (t) ê(t)= r i=1 h i (θ(t)) Ci ξ(t)+ Di u(t) (4)
div.p: where ξ(t)
div.formula: Δ = [x T (t) xT (t)] T , ê(t) Δ = y(t) -ŷ(t),and
Ãi Δ = A i 0 0 Â Ẽi Δ = E i 0 0 Ê Bi Δ = B i B Ci Δ = [ C i -Ĉ ] Di Δ = D i - D ⎫ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎬ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎭ . (5
div.p: Before proceeding, we introduce the following definitions, which will be of help in deriving our main results in the sequel.
Definition 1: The equilibrium ξ * = 0 of the fuzzy stochastic system ( Σc ) in (4) with u(t) = 0 is mean-square asymptotically stable if its solution ξ(t) satisfies
div.formula: lim t→∞ E ξ (t, ξ(0)) 2 = 0.
div.p: Definition 2: Given a scalar γ > 0, the fuzzy stochastic system ( Σc ) in ( 4) is mean-square asymptotically stable with an H ∞ performance level γ if it is mean-square asymptotically stable when u(t) ≡ 0, and under zero initial condition and for all nonzero u(t) ∈ L 2 [0, ∞), the following holds:
div.formula: E ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ ∞ 0 êT (t)ê(t)dt ⎫ ⎬ ⎭ < γ 2 ∞ 0 u T (t)u(t) dt. (6
div.p: Therefore, the H ∞ model reduction problem addressed in this paper can be formulated as follows: Given the T-S fuzzy stochastic system (Σ) in ( 2) and a scalar γ > 0, determine a reduced-order model of ( Σ) in ( 3) such that the resulting error system ( Σc ) in ( 4) is mean-square asymptotically stable with an H ∞ performance level γ.
To end this section, we recall the following lemma, which will play a key role in the derivation of our main results in this paper.
Lemma 1 [9]:
div.formula: Let W = W T ∈ R n×n , U ∈ R n×m
div.p: , and V ∈ R k×n be given matrices, and suppose that rank(U ) < n and rank(V ) < n. Consider the problem of finding some matrix G satisfying
div.formula: W + U GV + (U GV ) T < 0.(7)
div.p: Then, ( 7) is solvable for G if and only if
div.formula: U ⊥ W U ⊥T < 0 V T⊥ W V T⊥T < 0.(8)
div.p: Furthermore, if (8) holds, then all the solutions of G are given by
div.formula: G = U + R ΨV + L + Φ -U + R U R ΦV L V + L with ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ Ψ = Π -1 Ξ 1 2 L V R ΛV T R -1/2 -Π -1 U T L ΛV T R V R ΛV T R -1 Λ = U L Π -1 U T L -W -1 > 0 Ξ = Π -U T L Λ -ΛV T R V R ΛV T R -1 V R Λ U L > 0
div.p: where Φ, Π, and L are any appropriately dimensioned matrices satisfying Π > 0 and L < 1.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: First, we give the following result without proof; the detailed proof can be found in [29].
Lemma 2: Given a scalar γ > 0, the error system ( Σc ) in ( 4) is mean-square asymptotically stable with an H ∞ performance level γ if there exists a matrix P > 0 such that, for i = 1, 2, . . . , r
div.formula: ⎡ ⎢ ⎣ P Ãi + ÃT i P P Bi ẼT i P CT i -γ 2 I 0 DT i -P 0 -I ⎤ ⎥ ⎦ < 0. (9
div.p: Based on the result in Lemma 2, in what follows, we will provide two different approaches to solve the H ∞ model reduction for the T-S fuzzy stochastic system (Σ) in (2): One makes use of the convex linearization procedure, and the other is based on the projection lemma.

div.head: A. Convex Linearization Approach
div.p: We are now ready to present a solution to the H ∞ model reduction for system (Σ).

Theorem 1: Consider the T-S fuzzy stochastic system (Σ) in (2). There exists a reduced-order model ( Σ) in the form of (3) that solves the H ∞ model reduction problem with (6) satisfied, if there exist matrices P > 0, Q > 0, A, B, C, D, and

div.p: Observe that, since P > 0, we have that M > 0 for α > 0 in the neighborhood of the origin. Thus, it can be easily verified that there exists an arbitrarily small α > 0 such that M 4 is nonsingular and ( 9) is feasible with P replaced by M . Since M 4 is nonsingular, we thus conclude that there is no loss of generality to assume the matrix P 4 to be nonsingular.

div.p: Considering ( 16), we can obtain LMI (10) from (15). Moreover, notice that ( 14) is equivalent to

Notice also that the matrices Â, B, Ĉ, D, and Ê in (3) can be written as (17), which implies that P -T 4 P 3 can be viewed as a similarity transformation on the state-space realization of the filter and, as such, has no effect on the filter mapping from u to ŷ. Without loss of generality, we may set P -T 4 P 3 = I, thus obtaining (11). Therefore, the filter ( Σ) in (3) can be constructed by (11). This completes the proof.
Remark 2: Notice that the obtained conditions in Theorem 1 are all in LMI form; the fuzzy-rule-independent H ∞ model reduction can be determined by solving the following convex optimization problem:
div.formula: P>0,Q>0 min A,B,C,D,E δ subject to (10) (where δ = γ 2 ).(18)
div.p: When E i = 0 in (2), there is no Brownian motion, and the system (Σ) becomes a common T-S fuzzy system (Φ) which has the following form:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ẋ(t) = r i=1 h i (θ(t)) {A i x(t) + B i u(t)} y(t) = r i=1 h i (θ(t)) {C i x(t) + D i u(t)} . (19
div.p: Then, we have the following corollary for the T-S fuzzy system (Φ) in (19).

Corollary 1: Consider the T-S fuzzy system (Φ) in (19). There exists a reduced-order model ( Σ) in the form of (3) with Ê = 0 that solves the H ∞ model reduction problem with (6) satisfied, if there exist matrices P > 0, Q > 0, A, B, C, and

div.p: where the notations are defined in Theorem 1. Moreover, if the aforementioned conditions are feasible, then the system matrices of an admissible H ∞ reduced-order model can be calculated from

div.head: B. Projection Approach
div.p: In what follows, based on Lemma 1, we will solve the H ∞ model reduction problem.

Theorem 2: Consider the T-S fuzzy stochastic system (Σ) in (2). There exists a reduced-order model ( Σ) in the form of (3) that solves the H ∞ model reduction problem with (6) satisfied, if there exist matrices P > 0 and È > 0 such that, for

div.p: where Π and L are any matrices satisfying Π > 0, L < 1, and
div.formula: W Δ = ⎡ ⎢ ⎣ P Āi + ĀT i P P Bi ĒT i P CT i -γ 2 I 0 DT i -P 0 -I ⎤ ⎥ ⎦ U Δ = X T 1 P T 0 (p+2k)×m X T 3 P T X T 2 T V Δ = [ Y 1 Y 2 0 (m+k)×(n+k) 0 (m+k)×p ] Āi Δ = A i 0 n×k 0 k×n 0 k×k Ēi Δ = E i 0 n×k 0 k×n 0 k×k Ci Δ = [C i 0 p×k ] X 3 Δ = 0 n×p 0 n×k 0 n×k 0 k×p 0 k×k I k×k X 1 Δ = 0 n×p 0 n×k 0 n×k 0 k×p I k×k 0 k×k Bi Δ = B i 0 k×m Y 1 Δ = 0 m×n 0 m×k 0 k×n I k×k Y 2 Δ = I m×m 0 k×m Di Δ = D i X 2 Δ = [-I p×p 0 p×k 0 p×k ] H Δ = [I n×n 0 n×k ] ⎫ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎬ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎭ . div.p: Proof: Rewrite Ãi , Bi , Ci , Di , and Ẽi in (5) in the following form:
div.formula: Ãi Δ = Āi + X 1 GY 1 Bi Δ = Bi + X 1 GY 2 Ci Δ = Ci + X 2 GY 1 Di Δ = Di + X 2 GY 2 Ẽi Δ = Ēi + X 3 GY 1 ⎫ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎬ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎭(28)
div.p: where G, Āi , Bi , Ci , Di , Ēi , X j , and Y k , with j = 1, 2, 3 and k = 1, 2, are defined in ( 25) and (27). With (28), LMI (9) can be rewritten as

div.p: where W , U , and V are defined in (27). We choose
where H is defined in (27). Then, by Lemma 1, inequality ( 29) is solvable for G if and only if
div.formula: U ⊥ W U T⊥ < 0 V T⊥ W V ⊥ < 0
div.p: which can be formulated specifically as ⎡ ⎣
div.formula: H Āi P -1 +P -1 ĀT i H T H Bi HP -1 ĒT i H T -γ 2 I 0 -HP -1 H T ⎤ ⎦ <0 (30) ⎡ ⎣ H P Āi + ĀT i P H T H ĒT i P H CT i -P 0 -I ⎤ ⎦ <0. (31
div.p: By noting that È Δ = P -1 , it follows that ( 30) and ( 31) imply ( 22) and ( 23), respectively. In addition, when ( 22)-( 24) are satisfied, the parameterization ( 25) of all reduced-order models corresponding to a feasible solution can be obtained by using the results in [9] and [14]. This completes the proof.

By using the projection approach, in the following, we will give the corresponding result for the T-S fuzzy system (Φ) in (19). The result can be proved by following the same line as the proof of Theorem 2.

Corollary 2: Consider the T-S fuzzy stochastic system (Φ) in (19). There exists a reduced-order model ( Σ) in the form of (3) with Ê = 0 that solves the H ∞ model reduction problem with (6) satisfied, if there exist matrices P > 0 and È > 0 such that, for i = 1, 2, . . . , r
div.formula: H Āi È + È ĀT i H T H Bi -γ 2 I < 0(32)
H P Āi + ĀT i P H T H CT i -I < 0 (33
div.p: Moreover, if the aforementioned conditions are feasible, then the system matrices of an admissible H ∞ reduced-order model can be calculated from
div.formula: G Δ = D Ĉ B Â(35)
div.p: where
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ G = -Π -1 U T ΛV T (VΛV T ) -1 +Π -1 Ξ 1 2 L(VΛV T ) -1/2 Λ = (U Π -1 U T -W ) -1 > 0 Ξ = Π -U T Λ-ΛV T (VΛV T ) -1 VΛ U >0 (36
div.p: where Π and L are any matrices satisfying Π > 0 and L < 1 and the notations are defined as in Theorem 2.

Notice that the solvability conditions in Theorem 2 are not all in LMI form due to the matrix equality (24). We suggest the following minimization problem involving LMI conditions instead of the original nonconvex feasibility problem formulated in Theorem 2.
Problem H ∞ -MRTSFSS:
min trace (P È)
subject to (22) and (23) and
div.formula: P I I È ≥ 0. (37
div.p: We suggest the following algorithm to solve the aforementioned minimization problem.
Algorithm H ∞ -MRTSFSS:
Step 1) Find a feasible set (P (0) , È (0) ) satisfying ( 22), (23), and (37). Set κ = 0.
Step 2) Solve the following optimization problem:
div.formula: min trace P (κ) È + P È (κ)
div.p: subject to (22), (23), and (37) and denote f * to be the optimized value.
Step 3) Substitute the obtained matrix variables (P, È) into (30). If ( 30) is satisfied, with
for a sufficiently small scalar δ > 0, then output the feasible solutions (P, È). Exit.
Step 4) If κ > N, where N is the maximum number of iterations allowed, exit.
Step 5) Set κ = κ + 1 and (P (κ) , È (κ) ) = (P, È), and go to
Step 2.

Remark 3: Notice from Theorem 1 that, to cast the considered H ∞ reduced-order model design into a convex optimization problem in Remark 2, the matrix H, called here as an order reduction factor, plays a key role in the reduced-order model design. However, some conservativeness has been introduced due to the fact that the matrix H defined in Theorem 1 has a fixed structure, which can be seen as a main disadvantage of using the convex linearization approach to the model reduction problem. To conquer the disadvantage of the convex linearization approach, the projection approach is then used in Theorem 2 to solve the H ∞ model reduction problem. The projection approach does not need to introduce such an order reduction factor of H, but the compromise is that the solvability conditions in Theorem 2 are not all in the LMI form.

Remark 4: It is noted that these conditions in Theorem 2 are not a convex set due to the matrix equality constraints in (24). Several approaches have been proposed to solve such nonconvex feasibility problems, among which the cone complementarity linearization method [6] is the most commonly used one. According to El Ghaoui et al. [6], if the solution of the aforementioned minimization problem is (n + k), i.e., min trace(P È) = (n + k) (where n and k are the orders of the original system and the reduced-order model, respectively), then the conditions in Theorem 2 are solvable.

Remark 5: In Algorithm H ∞ Model Reduction for T-S Fuzzy Stochastic Systems (H ∞ -MRTSFSS), we employed the iteration method to solve the minimization problem involving LMI conditions instead of the original nonconvex feasibility problem formulated in (24). To obtain the optimal results in this minimization problem, the restrictive conditions, which should include the matrix variable P -1 and the given minimum errors |f * -2(n + k)|, should be checked. We can get the optimal results by checking whether the feasible solutions are satisfied with these conditions. If not, the iteration method should pause, and then, we get the ideal reduced-order model.

div.head: IV. ILLUSTRATIVE EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we will present two examples to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed techniques in this paper.
Example 1: Consider the T-S fuzzy stochastic system (Σ) in (2) with the model parameters given as follows:

0.2 0.1 0.2 0.0 0.0 0.03 0.1 0.2 0.02 0.1 0.2 0.0 0.1 0.0 0.1 0.3 Here, we are interested in finding reduced-order systems (Case 1: k = 3; Case 2: k = 2; Case 3: k = 1) in the form of ( Σ) in (3) to approximate the aforementioned system in an H ∞ sense by using the convex linearization and the projection approaches, respectively.
First, we consider the convex linearization approach. Solving (10) and ( 11), we have the results for different cases which are given in ( 38)-( 40), shown at the bottom of the page.

Case 1) With k = 3, the minimum γ is γ * = 0.277, and Now, we will consider the projection approach. Solving the nonconvex feasibility problem of Problem H ∞ -MRTSFSS with Algorithm H ∞ -MRTSFSS, the obtained results for different cases are given in (41)-( 43), shown at the bottom of the page.

The achieved γ * for these two approaches can be arranged in Table I. From Table I, we can see that the projection approach is less conservative than the convex linearization approach, as said in Remark 3.

In addition, to show the model reduction performances of the obtained reduced-order systems, let the initial condition be zero, i.e., x(0) = 0 (x(0) = 0; x(0) = 0), and suppose the membership functions to be ⎧ ⎨ ⎩

div.p: which are shown in Fig. 1, and the exogenous input u(t) to be u(t) = exp(-t) sin(t), t≥ 0.

Fig. 2 shows the outputs of the original system (2) (black line), the third-order reduced model (38) (red line), the Case 1) With k = 3, the minimum γ is γ * = 0.0065, and (43) second-order reduced model (39) (blue line), and the first-order reduced model (40) (green line) due to the aforementioned input signal. The output errors between the original system and the reduced models are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 4 shows the outputs of the original system (2) (black line), the third-order reduced model (41) (red line), the second-order reduced model (42) (blue line), and the first-order reduced model (43) (green line) due to the aforementioned input signal. The output errors between the original system and the reduced models are shown in Fig. 5.

Example 2: Consider a tunnel diode circuit shown in Fig. 6, whose fuzzy modeling was done in [2], where x 1 (t) = v C (t), x 2 (t) = i L (t), u(t) is the disturbance noise input, and y(t) is the measurement output. Thus, the circuit system can be approximated by the following two-rule T-S fuzzy model. Fig. 7 shows the membership functions for Rules 1 and 2.

Here, we are interested in finding reduced-order models in the form of ( Σ) in ( 3) with Ê = 0, to approximate the aforementioned system in an H ∞ sense by using the convex linearization approach. Solving (20), we obtain that the In addition, to show the model reduction performances of the obtained reduced-order model, let the initial condition be zero, i.e., x(0) = 0 (x(0) = 0; x(0) = 0), and the disturbance noise input u(t) be u(t) = exp(-2t) sin(3t), with t ≥ 0. Fig. 8 shows the outputs of the original system (black line) and the aforementioned reduced-order model (green line), and the output error between the original system and the reduced model is shown in Fig. 9.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the H ∞ model reduction problem has been studied for T-S fuzzy stochastic systems by using two different approaches, i.e., the convex linearization approach and the projection approach. Sufficient conditions have been established to solve the reduced-order models by using these two approaches. The presented numerical examples have shown the utility of the proposed methods.
